awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is to  monitor  sleep quality of individuals and report sleep quality index and sleep architecture using an ambient connected sensor. This project will potentially improve quality of care in some patient populations such as Alzheimer/Dementia patients and infants by enabling sleep quality assessment using a non-intrusive technology.   The passive sensor we have developed can precisely detect entire sleep stages as well as any abnormalities related to breathing or movement during sleep. The sensor is placed outside of bed and does not pose discomfort to the patient. It is our goal to offer a sleep sensor that will be an essential part of our healthy lifestyle choices.  The sensor must be non-intrusive and ambient to be widely accepted. Wearable or body-contact sensors take away from the natural sensation of sleep and might create a feeling of being monitored. For this reason, we believe an ideal sleep monitor should be ambient and easily blend in with the accessories on the bedside table. This monitor will enable the same kind of diagnostic power available in a hospital, to the comfort of our bedrooms. 

This I-Corps project proposes a sleep monitor based on a passive infrared sensing technology which utilizes a pyroelectric material for temperature sensing.  The material is lithium tantalate, a crystal that has pyroelectric properties. A change in ambient temperature creates a change in polarization of the crystal. This change creates a potential across the crystal and a charge is generated similar to a capacitor.  The generated charge is collected by electrodes thus we obtain the voltage response of the pyroelectric detector.  Under constant and ambient temperature, the response quickly approaches steady state. Due to the thermal time constant, the crystal will quickly thermalize to its environment after input. Thus, we observe a 'voltage pulse' mechanism when there is a fast change (physical movement) against the background. This property makes our sensor very sensitive to fluctuations against the background temperature distribution and allows it to accurately detect fine movements such as chest motion during breathing.  We use these fine chest movements to detect respiration and heart rate which in turn are used to  determine the sleep stage.  We use respiration rate variability to determine sleep stages and derive sleep quality index using sophisticated signal processing methods.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Global sleep wake disorders market was valued at about $20 Billion in 2016 and is projected to reach almost $60 Billion in 2023, which translates into almost 17% CAGR. North America is the largest market share at 35%.  In 2015, American Sleep Association and American Academy of Sleep Medicine estimated that over 70 million American adults have sleep disorders, costing USA over $150 Billion a year in lost productivity, accidents and increased healthcare utilization. Our research group has been developing an ambient sleep and respiration rate monitoring.

The passive infrared (PIR) sensor is very sensitive to temperature fluctuations against background temperature distribution and allows accurate detection of fine movements such as chest and head motion during breathing. The time-varying signal generated by the sensor due to chest and head movements is used  determine the respiration rate  and in return as an indirect metric for sleep stage.


This project aims to explore market potential for the ambient sensors and develop a business value proposition and develop a plan for minimum viable product through in person interviews to confirm our early adapter costumer population.   

Our team participated in  NSF I-Corps program ( Award Number : 1848689,  "Ambient Sleep Monitor")   and successfully completed the program during Winter Cohort in San Francisco between January 28 2019 and March 12 2019.  We have conducted over 103 interviews during the program to identify the primary market segment for our product, validate the problem addressed and the solution developed. Identify market leaders, potential competition,  solution partners for production and marketing and identify roadblocks that will effect the product development and commercialization.   

The interviews we conducted let us to pivot to respiration monitoring in hospitals as the primary market and identify sleep monitoring to the secondary market.  Discovery interviews were continued after the completion of the NSF I-Corps  program when we  have secured the support of two pulmonary medicine clinicians. Two prominent medical institutions, National Jewish Health in Denver and  the University of Chicago Hospital agreed to support our research with validation  and providing domain expertise.  

The outcomes of this project  include: 

  1. Conducted 103 interviews with potential customers, medical domain experts,  regulatory affairs experts, potential solution partners and marketing partners. 
  2. Developed  a prototype sensor to be used for data collection for validation.  Twenty sensor units has been built and shared with partner researchers in two hospitals, University of Chicago (Dr. Gokhan Mutlu,  pulmonary and critical care and sleep medicine)  and  National Jewish Hospital in Denver (Dr. Brian Modena,  Division of Allergy & Clinical Immunology)
  3. An IRB is obtained from San Diego State University Institutional Research Board and data collection experiments has been conducted.  A master student (Kim Phan)  is currently finishing her thesis on this subject. (IRB Protocol Number: HS-2018-0259). 
  4. Respiration and sleep data has been acquired from subjects over a week. 
  5. A Master student finished her thesis  on Ambient Respiration Rate Monitoring (Kavisha Saraswat). https://digitallibrary.sdsu.edu/islandora/object/sdsu%3A27556
  6. Submitted an SBIR proposal(Tracking Number: 2015129,  SBIR Phase I: Non-Contact Respiratory Rate Monitoring) to NSF. The proposal was declined  as the reviewers did not find it market ready yet and cited the need for complex algorithm, 
  7. Submitted  PFI  grant application  (Pending Review,  Tracking Number : 2044573, PFI-TT: Non-Contact Respiratory Rate Monitoring System Employing Passive Infrared Sensors) to address research and development challenges.  
  8. Filed a patent application “METHOD AND SYSTEM FOR MONITORING A SUBJECT IN A SLEEP OR RESTING STATE”, Publication Number:  20200196942.
